<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_device_open:
```c
int metal_device_open(const char *bus_name, const char *dev_name,
		      struct metal_device **device)
{
	struct metal_bus *bus;
	int error;

	if (!bus_name || !strlen(bus_name) ||
	    !dev_name || !strlen(dev_name) ||
	    !device)
		return -EINVAL;

	error = metal_bus_find(bus_name, &bus);
	if (error)
		return error;

	if (!bus->ops.dev_open)
		return -ENODEV;

	error = (*bus->ops.dev_open)(bus, dev_name, device);
	if (error)
		return error;

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_device_open:
int metal_bus_find(const char *name, struct metal_bus **result)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_bus *bus;

	metal_list_for_each(&_metal.common.bus_list, node) {
		bus = metal_container_of(node, struct metal_bus, node);
		if (strcmp(bus->name, name) == 0 && result) {
			*result = bus;
			return 0;
		}
	}
	return -ENOENT;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (!bus_name || !strlen(bus_name) ||
    !dev_name || !strlen(dev_name) ||
    !device)
	return -EINVAL;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The use of strlen() is guarded by the preceding NULL check in the same || expression; due to the left-to-right short-circuit evaluation of ||, strlen(bus_name) (and strlen(dev_name)) is only evaluated when the respective pointer is non-NULL, so there is no access beyond the bounds of the objects.
